Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Anatomy and Evolutionary Relationships of Klamelisaurus Gobiensis and Other Sauropod Dinosaurs of the Middle and Late Jurassic of China
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sauropod dinosaurs are the largest terrestrial animals ever to have lived. The sauropod body plan--characterized by elongated necks, massive bodies, and air-filled bones--emerged in the Middle and Late Jurassic, some evolving neck lengths exceeding nine meters. It is not known how and why body forms evolve. So far, no fewer than twenty sauropods from the Middle and Late Jurassic of China were found. Yet most remain to be studied. Through collaboration with Dr. Xu Xing of the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology, an international authority on dinosaur evolution, this project will exhaustively document the anatomy of Klamelisaurus gobiensis, an understudied sauropod from the Middle-Late Jurassic of China. New anatomical data from Klamelisaurus and other Chinese sauropods will be used to produce a revised hypothesis of sauropod evolutionary relationships and illuminate the mechanisms by which long necks evolved.

The holotype of Klamelisaurus gobiensis preserves a largely complete postcranial skeleton. The researcher will spend a significant portion of the EAPSI program producing a monographic anatomical description of Klamelisaurus. In addition, the researcher will reassess sauropod evolutionary relationships with a large morphological character matrix that includes numerous Chinese sauropods that have never been included in such an analysis, specifically addressing the hypothesis that Klamelisaurus is an early member of the exceptionally long-necked Omeisauridae. Phylogenetic analyses will be performed under both maximum parsimony and Bayesian posterior probability optimality criteria in the programs TNT and BEAST. The resulting evolutionary trees will be used to statistically test the likelihood of different evolutionary hypotheses regarding neck elongation, e.g., air space increases in anterior cervical vertebrae prior to the cervicalization of dorsal vertebrae. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Of particular interest to many sauropod dinosaur researchers is the evolution of the elongate neck that characterizes the group. Though an elongate neck is an ancestral feature of sauropods, necks exceeding nine meters in length apparently evolved no fewer than three times in sauropod evolutionary history. Such convergent evolution produces, in effect, semi-independent replicates that can be studied using statistical methods that account for evolutionary relatedness. In this framework, a researcher can test explicit hypotheses regarding the morphological, biomechanical, and ecological demands governing the evolution of exceptionally long necks. 

Chinese sauropods of the Middle and Late Jurassic were among the first sauropods to evolve exceptionally long necks, with some species of the Middle-Late Jurassic sauropod Mamenchisaurus bearing necks 12 meters in length. However, most of these Chinese sauropods have not been adequately described, and many have not been included in modern analyses of evolutionary relatedness. This lack of devoted research on their anatomy and evolution hinders robust quantitative analysis and hypothesis testing. 

The fellowship funded by this award allowed the primary investigator to exhaustively document the anatomy of Klamelisaurus gobiensis, a little-studied dinosaur previously hypothesized to be a member of an endemic group of exceptionally long-necked Chinese sauropods. Under the guidance of paleontologist Dr. Xu Xing, the primary investigator studied Klamelisaurus and numerous other sauropod dinosaur specimens at the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology in Beijing and the Zigong Dinosaur Museum in Sichuan Province. Preliminary results produce explicit hypotheses for the evolutionary interrelationships of poorly studied sauropod dinosaurs (e.g., Abrosaurus, Daanosaurus, Klamelisaurus), most of which have never before been included in a quantitative evolutionary analysis. These novel hypotheses bear directly on the biogeographic history of sauropods and the connectedness of East Asia to other paleocontinents in the Middle and Late Jurassic. Anatomical data gathered from Klamelisaurus and other sauropods suggest a combination of general and lineage-specific mechanisms of neck elongation.

The study of life in deep time is an inherently global endeavor, demanding international collaboration and reciprocal knowledge sharing. This project provided the primary investigator with first-hand research experience outside the U.S., an orientation to Chinese culture, language, and science policy, and the opportunity to forge intergenerational collaborations with top Chinese scholars, and thus meets NSF Broader Impact goals of developing partnerships with international academic institutions and ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Data related to this project will be made publicly available via the Morphobank website upon publication of results.
